text:
Hi peoples. I'm having problems installing Gtk.jl in a machine. It works fine in another machine, but on the new one I seem to have problems with a dependency

```julia> using Gtk
[ Info: Precompiling Gtk [4c0ca9eb-093a-5379-98c5-f87ac0bbbf44]
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: InitError: could not load library "/home/user/.julia/artifacts/76b60565e02edacb1b13d24771099d813ecad6f9/lib/libicudata.so"
/home/user/.julia/artifacts/76b60565e02edacb1b13d24771099d813ecad6f9/lib/libicudata.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory```
The same artifacts directory has more stuff on the other machine. Could I just copy stuff around? What could cause this? Or maybe an older version might work?...

elements.text: Hi peoples. I'm having problems installing Gtk.jl in a machine. It works fine in another machine, but on the new one I seem to have problems with a dependency

julia> using Gtk
[ Info: Precompiling Gtk [4c0ca9eb-093a-5379-98c5-f87ac0bbbf44]
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: InitError: could not load library "/home/user/.julia/artifacts/76b60565e02edacb1b13d24771099d813ecad6f9/lib/libicudata.so"
/home/user/.julia/artifacts/76b60565e02edacb1b13d24771099d813ecad6f9/lib/libicudata.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
The same artifacts directory has more stuff on the other machine. Could I just copy stuff around? What could cause this? Or maybe an older version might work?...

text: I think just deleting my .julia and installing things from scratch solves it, but how could I have reset only that package without having to nuke my whole .julia? Why doesn't removing and adding again does the trick?

elements.text: I think just deleting my .julia and installing things from scratch solves it, but how could I have reset only that package without having to nuke my whole .julia? Why doesn't removing and adding again does the trick?

text:
Deleting the entire `.julia` directory is never a good idea, nor useful. It's better to delete something more specific, and less harmful. Here I'd have tried cleaning up first the `compiled` directory

> Why doesn't removing and adding again does the trick?
> 
Well, it should... Just `using` the package should trigger download if the artifact isn't there already
